data.title: SEVERE FLOODING: Llano River rages, destroys bridge in Llano
data.meta_description: UPDATE at 12: 30 p. m. : The National Weather Service states the Llano River has crested; a secondary crest is expected Wednesday morning. ___. UPDATE at 9:30 a. m. : The raging Llano River caused a bridge in Kingsland to collapse. (video below) The LCRA has also closed lakes Travis, Marble Falls, LBJ, Inks and Buchanan effective immediately, until further notice. ___.
data.text:
UPDATE at 12: 30 p.m.: The National Weather Service states the Llano River has crested; a secondary crest is expected Wednesday morning.

___

UPDATE at 9:30 a.m.: The raging Llano River caused a bridge in Kingsland to collapse. (video below)

The LCRA has also closed lakes Travis, Marble Falls, LBJ, Inks and Buchanan effective immediately, until further notice.

___

The Llano Office of Emergency Management urged residents living close to the Llano River to evacuate and seek higher ground on Tuesday as the river continued to rise.

The National Weather Service tweeted the river was above 38 feet and rising at about 6 a.m. The service added that low-lying areas along the river are vulnerable to flooding.

People living within a quarter mile of the river were told to immediately seek higher ground.

Two shelters were reportedly set up in Llano.

___

Forecasters warn of 'dangerous' flooding along Llano River

By the Associated Press

LLANO, Texas (AP) -- Forecasters are telling people along the Llano River in Central Texas to seek higher ground after more than 10 inches of rain fell in the past day and a half.

The National Weather Service says the river at Llano, about 65 miles (105 kilometers) northwest of Austin, is expected to crest Tuesday morning at near-record levels. A flash flood warning is in effect, and forecasters describe it as a "very dangerous situation."

The river was expected to crest at near 41 feet (12.5 meters), which is 18 feet (5.5 meters) above major flood stage. It's not expected to drop below major flood stage until Wednesday.

Last week, four people were swept away in floodwaters along the South Llano River in Junction. The bodies of three were recovered and one person remains missing.
